elements.content: We report the use of the organometallic linker [Cp*Ir(η4-benzoquinone)] (1b) LIr to construct novel supramolecular one- and two-dimensional (1D and 2D) coordination polymers {[Cu2(LIr)2(CH3CN)(OTf)2][LIr](OTf)} n (3) and {[Ag2(CH3CN)2][LIr]2(OTf)2} n (4). Complex 3 formed a zigzag chain of Cu(I) and Cu(II) centers connected through irido-quinonoid backbones, while complex 4 exhibited argentopilic Ag---Ag d10---d10 contacts at d = 3.638 Å and C---H/π interactions between the 1D chain neighbors.
elements.clean_text: We report the use of the organometallic linker [Cp*Ir(η4-benzoquinone)] (1b) LIr to construct novel supramolecular one- and two-dimensional (1D and 2D) coordination polymers {[Cu2(LIr)2(CH3CN)(OTf)2][LIr](OTf)} n  (3) and {[Ag2(CH3CN)2][LIr]2(OTf)2} n  (4). Complex 3 formed a zigzag chain of Cu(I) and Cu(II) centers connected through irido-quinonoid backbones, while complex 4 exhibited argentopilic Ag---Ag d10---d10 contacts at d = 3.638 Å and C---H/π interactions between the 1D chain neighbors.

elements.content: We report the use of the organometallic linker [Cp*Ir(η4-benzoquinone)] (1b) LIr to construct novel supramolecular one- and two-dimensional coordination polymers {[Cu2(LIr)2(CH3CN)(OTf)2][LIr](OTf)} n (3) and {[Ag2(CH3CN)2][LIr]2(OTf)2} n (4) exhibiting as outstanding features coinage metals as nodes and irido-quinonoid backbones.
elements.clean_text: We report the use of the organometallic linker [Cp*Ir(η4-benzoquinone)] (1b) LIr to construct novel supramolecular one- and two-dimensional coordination polymers {[Cu2(LIr)2(CH3CN)(OTf)2][LIr](OTf)} n  (3) and {[Ag2(CH3CN)2][LIr]2(OTf)2} n  (4) exhibiting as outstanding features coinage metals as nodes and irido-quinonoid backbones.

elements.content: Self-assembly of coordination polymers is at present an intensely active research area. Most of these supramolecular species are constructed via a combination of metal ions of different coordination geometries and organic bridging ligands. Such coordination polymers could have many applications, including molecular wires and semiconductors and in magnetics, catalysis, separations, and host−guest interactions. It is therefore important to design specific linkers that can bind to metal ions and provide novel supramolecular polymers with new properties. In this context, we have designed the organometallic linkers [Cp*M(η4-benzoquinone)], M = Rh, LRh (1a); M = Ir, LIr (1b), and showed their ability to construct one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers of formula {[Ag3(LM)2(CH3CN)2(OTf)][LM](OTf)2} n (2a,b) (Scheme ). We anticipate that such materials with organometallo-ligand linkers may exhibit different properties not available in coordination polymers with usual organic linkers. Pursuing our research in this area of “supramolecular assemblies with quinonoid linkers”, we report in this paper two novel appealing architectures, a 1D supramolecular zigzag coordination polymer {[Cu2(LIr)2(CH3CN)(OTf)2][LIr](OTf)} n (3) with secondary building units (SBUs) of copper ions and a two-dimensional (2D) network {[Ag2(CH3CN)2][LIr]2(OTf)2} n (4) exhibiting as outstanding features the formation of enchained metallomacrocycles with weak Ag---Ag argentophilic interactions. Moreover, the photoluminescent properties of complexes 2a and 2b with short Ag···Ag interactions (d = 3.37 Å) are presented.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Self-assembly of coordination polymers is at present an intensely active research area. Most of these supramolecular species are constructed via a combination of metal ions of different coordination geometries and organic bridging ligands. Such coordination polymers could have many applications, including molecular wires and semiconductors and in magnetics, catalysis, separations, and host-guest interactions. It is therefore important to design specific linkers that can bind to metal ions and provide novel supramolecular polymers with new properties. In this context, we have designed the organometallic linkers [Cp*M(η4-benzoquinone)], M = Rh, LRh (1a); M = Ir, LIr (1b), and showed their ability to construct one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymers of formula {[Ag3(LM)2(CH3CN)2(OTf)][LM](OTf)2} n  (2a,b) (Scheme ). We anticipate that such materials with organometallo-ligand linkers may exhibit different properties not available in coordination polymers with usual organic linkers. Pursuing our research in this area of "supramolecular assemblies with quinonoid linkers", we report in this paper two novel appealing architectures, a 1D supramolecular zigzag coordination polymer {[Cu2(LIr)2(CH3CN)(OTf)2][LIr](OTf)} n  (3) with secondary building units (SBUs) of copper ions and a two-dimensional (2D) network {[Ag2(CH3CN)2][LIr]2(OTf)2} n  (4) exhibiting as outstanding features the formation of enchained metallomacrocycles with weak Ag---Ag argentophilic interactions. Moreover, the photoluminescent properties of complexes 2a and 2b with short Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions (d = 3.37 Å) are presented.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="cg060944lh00001" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic xlink:href="cg-2006-00944l_0002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Quinonoid metal complexes in which the ligand is π-bonded to the metal center are surprisingly rare. We have found that the “Cp*M” entity forms stable and soluble metalated quinone complexes [Cp*M(η4-benzoquinone)] M = Rh (1a); M = Ir (1b). More recently, we reported the first stable p-dithiobenzoquinone as a metal complex [Cp*Ir(η4-p-dithiobenzoquinone)] (1c). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations carried out on these complexes showed that a retro-donation of the metal center to the π-bonded ligand increases the nucleophilic character of the oxygen or the sulfur atoms, and eventually coordination of metal cations becomes easier.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Quinonoid metal complexes in which the ligand is π-bonded to the metal center are surprisingly rare. We have found that the "Cp*M" entity forms stable and soluble metalated quinone complexes [Cp*M(η4-benzoquinone)] M = Rh (1a); M = Ir (1b). More recently, we reported the first stable p-dithiobenzoquinone as a metal complex [Cp*Ir(η4-p-dithiobenzoquinone)] (1c). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations carried out on these complexes showed that a retro-donation of the metal center to the π-bonded ligand increases the nucleophilic character of the oxygen or the sulfur atoms, and eventually coordination of metal cations becomes easier.

elements.content: Treatment of 1b (Figure ) with the air-sensitive complex of Cu(I) triflate and benzene [(CuOTf)2(C6H6)] in CH2Cl2 resulted in a suspension, which was recrystallized from CH3CN/diethylether to give golden crystals of 3 (see experimental). The infrared spectrum of 2 shows the presence of two strong bands at 1261 and 1034 cm-1, which are assigned to the triflate anions. Further, two absorptions are visible at 1558 and 1508 cm-1, which are attributed to the CO groups of the coordinated benzoquinone. The 1H NMR of 3 recorded in acetone-d 6 shows the presence of broad singlets at δ 5.00 ppm for the diene protons and at δ 1.92 ppm for the η5-Cp*Ir moiety and a singlet at 2.08 ppm assigned to the coordinated CH3CN. To ascertain the identity of this complex 3, a single-crystal X-ray diffraction study was undertaken (Figure ). The structure of 3 shows the formation of a 1D zigzag coordination polymer. It consists of dimetallic copper nodes of formula [Cu2(LIr)2(CH3CN)(OTf)2]+ that are linked through η4-benzoquinone ligand LIr (1b) in a zigzag fashion. In this coordination polymer, the bimetallic copper clusters constitute so-called SBUs (Scheme ). Each SBU consists of one Cu(I) center with tetrahedral configuration and a Cu(II) center with square pyramidal configuration. The Cu(II) is coordinated to two triflate anions and to three quinone oxygen atoms, while the other Cu(I) atom is linked to three quinone oxygen atoms and coordinated to CH3CN (Scheme ). The Cu(I)---Cu(II) distance is 3.5 Å, indicative of the absence of interatomic contact (sum of van der Waals radii of Cu is 2.80 Å).

The infrared spectrum of 2 shows the presence of two strong bands at 1261 and 1034 cm-1, which are assigned to the triflate anions. Further, two absorptions are visible at 1558 and 1508 cm-1, which are attributed to the CO groups of the coordinated benzoquinone. The 1H NMR of 3 recorded in acetone-d 6 shows the presence of broad singlets at δ 5.00 ppm for the diene protons and at δ 1.92 ppm for the η5-Cp*Ir moiety and a singlet at 2.08 ppm assigned to the coordinated CH3CN. To ascertain the identity of this complex 3, a single-crystal X-ray diffraction study was undertaken (Figure ). The structure of 3 shows the formation of a 1D zigzag coordination polymer. It consists of dimetallic copper nodes of formula [Cu2(LIr)2(CH3CN)(OTf)2]+ that are linked through η4-benzoquinone ligand LIr (1b) in a zigzag fashion. In this coordination polymer, the bimetallic copper clusters constitute so-called SBUs (Scheme ). Each SBU consists of one Cu(I) center with tetrahedral configuration and a Cu(II) center with square pyramidal configuration. The Cu(II) is coordinated to two triflate anions and to three quinone oxygen atoms, while the other Cu(I) atom is linked to three quinone oxygen atoms and coordinated to CH3CN (Scheme ).  The Cu(I)---Cu(II) distance is 3.5 Å, indicative of the absence of interatomic contact (sum of van der Waals radii of Cu is 2.80 Å).

elements.content: Crystal view of the cationic part of the zigzag 1D coordination polymer3 with atom numbering system. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Selected atomic distances (Å) and angles (°):  Cu(1)−Cu(1) = 3.522, Cu(1)−N(1) = 1.884, Cu(1)−O(1) = 2.157, Cu(1)−O(3) = 2.088, Cu(2)−O(2) = 2.596(6), Cu(2)−O(4) = 2.427, Cu(1)−O(1)−Cu(2) = 98.58°, Cu(1)−O(3)−Cu(2) = 96.92, O(1)−Cu(1)−O(3) = 71.69° O(1)−Cu(2)−O(3) = 88.93°.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal view of the cationic part of the zigzag 1D coordination polymer3 with atom numbering system. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Selected atomic distances (Å) and angles (°): Cu(1)-Cu(1) = 3.522, Cu(1)-N(1) = 1.884, Cu(1)-O(1) = 2.157, Cu(1)-O(3) = 2.088, Cu(2)-O(2) = 2.596(6), Cu(2)-O(4) = 2.427, Cu(1)-O(1)-Cu(2) = 98.58°, Cu(1)-O(3)-Cu(2) = 96.92, O(1)-Cu(1)-O(3) = 71.69° O(1)-Cu(2)-O(3) = 88.93°.

elements.content: Self-Assembly of 1D Zigzag Polymer3 Showing the Secondary Building Unit (SBU) Connected by the Tridentate Organometallic Linker LIr (1b).
elements.clean_text: 2  Self-Assembly of 1D Zigzag Polymer3 Showing the Secondary Building Unit (SBU) Connected by the Tridentate Organometallic Linker LIr (1b).

elements.content: Interestingly, the organometallic linker LIr adopts a boat conformation in 3 with the quinone carbons bent out of the diene plane while acting as a tridentate ligand and connects three copper atoms such that one quinone oxygen is bidentate (hinge angle θ = 10.70°) and the other is monodentate (hinge angle θ = 17.29°) (Figure ). The SBUs in 3 are thus connected via a bidentate quinone oxygen of the organometallic linker LIr from one side and through a monodentate quinone oxygen atom from the opposite side resulting in a unique architecture for the 1D zigzag coordination polymer 3. It is worth mentioning that during the formation of 3 the air-sensitive starting material [(CuOTf)2(C6H6)] is partially oxidized to give some Cu(II) ions in solution, which are self-assembled in the presence of starting material CuOTf to give the target supramolecular assembly 3. It is worth mentioning that [(CuOTf)2(C6H6)] is well-known to disproportionate in solution to give Cu(0) and Cu(II) ions.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the organometallic linker LIr adopts a boat conformation in 3 with the quinone carbons bent out of the diene plane while acting as a tridentate ligand and connects three copper atoms such that one quinone oxygen is bidentate (hinge angle θ = 10.70°) and the other is monodentate (hinge angle θ = 17.29°) (Figure ). The SBUs in 3 are thus connected via a bidentate quinone oxygen of the organometallic linker LIr from one side and through a monodentate quinone oxygen atom from the opposite side resulting in a unique architecture for the 1D zigzag coordination polymer 3. It is worth mentioning that during the formation of 3 the air-sensitive starting material [(CuOTf)2(C6H6)] is partially oxidized to give some Cu(II) ions in solution, which are self-assembled in the presence of starting material CuOTf to give the target supramolecular assembly 3. It is worth mentioning that [(CuOTf)2(C6H6)] is well-known to disproportionate in solution to give Cu(0) and Cu(II) ions.

elements.content: To control the self-assembly process of the coordination polymer, we repeated the previous experiment with the stable coinage metal AgOTf in place of [(CuOTf)2(C6H6)] to avoid any side oxidation reactions. Thus, treatment of 1b with AgOTf in CH2Cl2 provided a brown suspension, which was dried under vacuum and then recrystallized from CH3CN/diethylether to give colorless crystals of 4 in 70% yield. The infrared spectrum of 4 shows the presence of two strong vibrations at 1278 and 1038 cm-1, which are assigned to the triflate anion; further, two strong absorptions are visible at 1610 and 1577 cm-1 and are attributed to the CO groups of the coordinated benzoquinone. The 1H NMR of 4 recorded in CD3CN shows the presence of singlets at δ 4.77 ppm, assigned to the diene protons, and at δ 2.02 ppm, attributed to the methyl protons of the η5-Cp*Ir moiety. To ascertain the identity of this complex, a single-crystal X-ray diffraction study was undertaken.
elements.clean_text: To control the self-assembly process of the coordination polymer, we repeated the previous experiment with the stable coinage metal AgOTf in place of [(CuOTf)2(C6H6)] to avoid any side oxidation reactions. Thus, treatment of 1b with AgOTf in CH2Cl2 provided a brown suspension, which was dried under vacuum and then recrystallized from CH3CN/diethylether to give colorless crystals of 4 in 70% yield. The infrared spectrum of 4 shows the presence of two strong vibrations at 1278 and 1038 cm-1, which are assigned to the triflate anion; further, two strong absorptions are visible at 1610 and 1577 cm-1 and are attributed to the CO groups of the coordinated benzoquinone. The 1H NMR of 4 recorded in CD3CN shows the presence of singlets at δ 4.77 ppm, assigned to the diene protons, and at δ 2.02 ppm, attributed to the methyl protons of the η5-Cp*Ir moiety. To ascertain the identity of this complex, a single-crystal X-ray diffraction study was undertaken.

elements.content: The structure shows the formation of a 2D coordination network (Figure ) as a result of weak edge-to-face π-stacking between the hydrogen atoms of the −CH3 groups of the η5-Cp* of one 1D coordination chain and the aromatic ring of another metalated η5-Cp*Ir moiety of another 1D coordination chain. The hydrogen atoms are located at 2.7−2.8 Å from the corresponding center of the ring. This observed distance is within the typical range of C−H/π interactions. Each 1D coordination chain can be better described as enchained metallomacrocycles of a 14-membered ring fused to a smaller four-membered cycle. In this supramolecular assembly, the η4-quinone ligand is coordinated to the silver ions through the oxygen atoms. Each silver ion has a tetrahedral configuration where the coordination sites are occupied by three oxygen centers and one CH3CN ligand. In a similar way to 3, one of the oxygen atoms of the η4-quinone ligand binds to two silver ions, while the other oxygen center coordinates to only one metal center. The Ag···Ag distance is 3.638 Å, suggesting a weak argentophilic interaction. Analogously to 3, the η4-benzoquinone unit in 4 adopts a boat conformation with hinge angles θ = 22.4° for the monodentate oxygen and θ = 15.9° for the bidentate oxygen, and as a result these carbon atoms are weakly coordinated to the Cp*Ir moiety. In contrast, the diene carbons are strongly coordinated to the metal center so that the overall structure is best described as an η4-quinone. The bridging benzoquinone rings in 4 are face to face at a short distance 3.17 Å but θ = 44° excluding any π−π interactions; the bulky η5-Cp*Ir moieties are pointing away from the benzoquinone in this 2D network 4.
elements.clean_text: The structure shows the formation of a 2D coordination network (Figure ) as a result of weak edge-to-face π-stacking between the hydrogen atoms of the -CH3 groups of the η5-Cp* of one 1D coordination chain and the aromatic ring of another metalated η5-Cp*Ir moiety of another 1D coordination chain. The hydrogen atoms are located at 2.7-2.8 Å from the corresponding center of the ring. This observed distance is within the typical range of C-H/π interactions. Each 1D coordination chain can be better described as enchained metallomacrocycles of a 14-membered ring fused to a smaller four-membered cycle. In this supramolecular assembly, the η4-quinone ligand is coordinated to the silver ions through the oxygen atoms. Each silver ion has a tetrahedral configuration where the coordination sites are occupied by three oxygen centers and one CH3CN ligand. In a similar way to 3, one of the oxygen atoms of the η4-quinone ligand binds to two silver ions, while the other oxygen center coordinates to only one metal center. The Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag distance is 3.638 Å, suggesting a weak argentophilic interaction. Analogously to 3, the η4-benzoquinone unit in 4 adopts a boat conformation with hinge angles θ = 22.4° for the monodentate oxygen and θ = 15.9° for the bidentate oxygen, and as a result these carbon atoms are weakly coordinated to the Cp*Ir moiety. In contrast, the diene carbons are strongly coordinated to the metal center so that the overall structure is best described as an η4-quinone. The bridging benzoquinone rings in 4 are face to face at a short distance 3.17 Å but θ = 44° excluding any π-π interactions; the bulky η5-Cp*Ir moieties are pointing away from the benzoquinone in this 2D network 4.

elements.content: Crystal view of the cationic part of the 2D network4 with atom numbering system. Hydrogens have been omitted for clarity except for hydrogens 172, which show the C−H/π interactions in 4. Selected atomic distances (Å) and angles (°):  Ag(1)−Ag(1) = 3.638, Ag(1)−N(1) = 2.192(11), Ag(1)−O(1) = 2.441(7), Ag(1)−O(2) = 2.253(6), Ag(1)−O(2) = 2.398(6), Ag(1)−O(2)−Ag(1) = 102.90°, O(2)−Ag(1)−O(2) = 77.10°.
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal view of the cationic part of the 2D network4 with atom numbering system. Hydrogens have been omitted for clarity except for hydrogens 172, which show the C-H/π interactions in 4. Selected atomic distances (Å) and angles (°): Ag(1)-Ag(1) = 3.638, Ag(1)-N(1) = 2.192(11), Ag(1)-O(1) = 2.441(7), Ag(1)-O(2) = 2.253(6), Ag(1)-O(2) = 2.398(6), Ag(1)-O(2)-Ag(1) = 102.90°, O(2)-Ag(1)-O(2) = 77.10°.

elements.content: Although in 3 and 4 the organometallic linker is a tridentate ligand, the structure of 4 is intrinsically different from that of 3. A simple comparison of the ratio of LIr/coinage metal (3:2) in 3 and (1:1) in 4 shows this difference. Furthermore, we attribute the difference of the two supramolecular assemblies 3 and 4 to the geometrical property of Cu(II) ions, which adopt a square pyramidal geometry, compared to the tetrahedral one of Cu(I) and Ag(I) ions.
elements.clean_text: Although in 3 and 4 the organometallic linker is a tridentate ligand, the structure of 4 is intrinsically different from that of 3. A simple comparison of the ratio of LIr/coinage metal (3:2) in 3 and (1:1) in 4 shows this difference. Furthermore, we attribute the difference of the two supramolecular assemblies 3 and 4 to the geometrical property of Cu(II) ions, which adopt a square pyramidal geometry, compared to the tetrahedral one of Cu(I) and Ag(I) ions.

elements.content: Discrete coinage metal complexes with d10---d10 interactions continue to generate much interest in terms of their luminescent properties. The short metal−metal contacts found in these metal complexes are believed to play a dominant role in the excited-state properties. Thus, we investigated the photophysical properties of our 1D supramolecular assemblies {[Ag3(LM)2(CH3CN)2(OTf)][LM](OTf)2} n (2a,b) because they present shorter Ag···Ag (3.37 Å) contacts compared to 4. Complexes 2a,b showed weak emissions at room temperature (298 K) in a solution of CH3CN with emission maxima at 421 nm (2a) and at 406 nm (2b). Repeating the above measurements but at 77 K glass in butyronitrile, complexes 2a and 2b exhibited a slight blue shift with emission maxima at 408 nm for 2a and 402 nm for 2b, respectively (Figure S, Supporting Information). We believe that these emissions are mainly due to a metal-perturbed intraligand emission of benzoquinone since benzoquinone also emits at similar energies, suggesting that these polymers dissociate in solution into oligomers that are in equilibrium. Attempts to measure the luminescent properties in the solid state were not successful since the complexes do not emit in the solid state, preventing a direct correlation of the emissive properties with the Ag···Ag interaction.
elements.clean_text: Discrete coinage metal complexes with d10---d10 interactions continue to generate much interest in terms of their luminescent properties. The short metal-metal contacts found in these metal complexes are believed to play a dominant role in the excited-state properties. Thus, we investigated the photophysical properties of our 1D supramolecular assemblies {[Ag3(LM)2(CH3CN)2(OTf)][LM](OTf)2} n  (2a,b) because they present shorter Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag (3.37 Å) contacts compared to 4. Complexes 2a,b showed weak emissions at room temperature (298 K) in a solution of CH3CN with emission maxima at 421 nm (2a) and at 406 nm (2b). Repeating the above measurements but at 77 K glass in butyronitrile, complexes 2a and 2b exhibited a slight blue shift with emission maxima at 408 nm for 2a and 402 nm for 2b, respectively (Figure S, Supporting Information). We believe that these emissions are mainly due to a metal-perturbed intraligand emission of benzoquinone since benzoquinone also emits at similar energies, suggesting that these polymers dissociate in solution into oligomers that are in equilibrium. Attempts to measure the luminescent properties in the solid state were not successful since the complexes do not emit in the solid state, preventing a direct correlation of the emissive properties with the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction.

elements.content: In summary, we have reported the use of 1b as organometallo-ligand linker. Interestingly, self-assembly of the irido-quinone LIr with copper and silver ions provided two different supramolecular assemblies 3 and 4 with quinonoid backbones. Complex 3 was identified as a 1D zigzag coordination polymer with SBUs composed of Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions. Complex 4 was characterized as a 2D network through C−H/π interactions between 1D polymers of enchained macrocycles featuring Ag···Ag argentophilic interactions. Further, the luminescent properties of the coordination polymers 2a,b with short Ag···Ag interactions are reported. These results illustrate the successful approach in using of the organometallo-ligand linkers LIr to construct a novel class of supramolecular assemblies when combined with different metal ions of different geometries.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have reported the use of 1b as organometallo-ligand linker. Interestingly, self-assembly of the irido-quinone LIr with copper and silver ions provided two different supramolecular assemblies 3 and 4 with quinonoid backbones. Complex 3 was identified as a 1D zigzag coordination polymer with SBUs composed of Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions. Complex 4 was characterized as a 2D network through C-H/π interactions between 1D polymers of enchained macrocycles featuring Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag argentophilic interactions. Further, the luminescent properties of the coordination polymers 2a,b with short Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions are reported. These results illustrate the successful approach in using of the organometallo-ligand linkers LIr to construct a novel class of supramolecular assemblies when combined with different metal ions of different geometries.

elements.content: All experimental manipulations were carried out under argon using Schlenk tube techniques. The 1H and 13C and spectra were recorded in (CD3)2CO and CD3CN using a Bruker AC 300 NMR spectrometer at 300.13 MHz, respectively. Infrared spectra were recorded from KBr discs on a Bio-Rad FT-IR spectrometer FTS 165. Steady-state emission spectra were recorded on a Spex Fluorolog-2 model F 111 fluorescence spectrofluorometer equipped with a Hamamatsu R-928 photomultiplier tube. All solutions for photophysical studies were rigorously degassed on a high-vacuum line with no less than four successive freeze−pump−thaw cycles. Complexes 2a and 2b were prepared according to published procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All experimental manipulations were carried out under argon using Schlenk tube techniques. The 1H and 13C and spectra were recorded in (CD3)2CO and CD3CN using a Bruker AC 300 NMR spectrometer at 300.13 MHz, respectively. Infrared spectra were recorded from KBr discs on a Bio-Rad FT-IR spectrometer FTS 165. Steady-state emission spectra were recorded on a Spex Fluorolog-2 model F 111 fluorescence spectrofluorometer equipped with a Hamamatsu R-928 photomultiplier tube. All solutions for photophysical studies were rigorously degassed on a high-vacuum line with no less than four successive freeze-pump-thaw cycles. Complexes 2a and 2b were prepared according to published procedures.

elements.content: Synthesis of 3. A solution of 1b (18 mg, 0.04 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (15 mL) was added to (CuOTf)2.C6H6 (10 mg, 0.02 mmol), and the mixture was stirred for 3 h. The solvent was reduced under vacuum to give an off-gray microcrystalline solid. This solid was washed with benzene and recrystallized from CH3CN/Et2O to give golden crystals. Yield:  84%. (m = 22 mg, 0.011 mmol). IR (KBr disc):  v(CO) 1558 cm-1, 1508 cm-1, v(SO) 1261 cm-1, v(C−F) 1034 cm-1. 1H NMR (300 MHz, acetone-d 6):  δ = 1.92 (s, 15H, η5-Cp*), 2.08 (br, 3H, coordinated CH3−CN), 5.00 (s, 4H, diene) ppm. Analysis calcld for C53H60O15F9S3NCu2Ir3.C6H6; C 35.43; H 3.33; N 0.70. Found C 35.30; H 3.32; N 0.59.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 3. A solution of 1b (18 mg, 0.04 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (15 mL) was added to (CuOTf)2.C6H6 (10 mg, 0.02 mmol), and the mixture was stirred for 3 h. The solvent was reduced under vacuum to give an off-gray microcrystalline solid. This solid was washed with benzene and recrystallized from CH3CN/Et2O to give golden crystals. Yield: 84%. (m = 22 mg, 0.011 mmol). IR (KBr disc): v(CO) 1558 cm-1, 1508 cm-1, v(SO) 1261 cm-1, v(C-F) 1034 cm-1. 1H NMR (300 MHz, acetone-d 6): δ = 1.92 (s, 15H, η5-Cp*), 2.08 (br, 3H, coordinated CH3-CN), 5.00 (s, 4H, diene) ppm. Analysis calcld for C53H60O15F9S3NCu2Ir3.C6H6; C 35.43; H 3.33; N 0.70. Found C 35.30; H 3.32; N 0.59.

elements.content: Synthesis of 4. A solution of 1b (50 mg, 0.11 mmol) in CH2Cl2 was added to AgOTf (41 mg, 0.16 mmol), and the mixture was stirred for 12 h. The solvent was reduced under vacuum to give an off-gray microcrystalline solid. This solid was recrystallized from CH3CN/Et2O to give colorless crystals. Yield:  70% (m = 56.4 mg, 0.077 mmol). IR (KBr disc):  v(−C⋮N) 2260 v(CO) 1610 cm-1, 1577 cm-1, v(SO) 1278 cm-1, v(C−F) 1038 cm-1. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3CN):  δ 2.02 (s, 15H, η5-Cp*), 2.45 (s, 3H, coordinated CH3−CN), 4.77 (s, 4H, diene) ppm. Analysis calcld for C19H22O5F3SNAgIr; C 31.1; H 3.0; N 1.9. Found C 31.7; H 3.2; N 2.1.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 4. A solution of 1b (50 mg, 0.11 mmol) in CH2Cl2 was added to AgOTf (41 mg, 0.16 mmol), and the mixture was stirred for 12 h. The solvent was reduced under vacuum to give an off-gray microcrystalline solid. This solid was recrystallized from CH3CN/Et2O to give colorless crystals. Yield: 70% (m = 56.4 mg, 0.077 mmol). IR (KBr disc): v(-C⋮N) 2260 v(CO) 1610 cm-1, 1577 cm-1, v(SO) 1278 cm-1, v(C-F) 1038 cm-1. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3CN): δ 2.02 (s, 15H, η5-Cp*), 2.45 (s, 3H, coordinated CH3-CN), 4.77 (s, 4H, diene) ppm. Analysis calcld for C19H22O5F3SNAgIr; C 31.1; H 3.0; N 1.9. Found C 31.7; H 3.2; N 2.1.

elements.content: X-ray Structural Analysis of 3 and 4. Crystals of 3 and 4 suitable for X-ray studies were grown from CH3CN/Et2O. In all cases, X-ray data collections with Mo Kα radiation were carried out at 250 K (3) and 298 K (4) using a Enraf-Nonius diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector. Crystal data for 3. Golden crystals:  C55 H63 Cu2 F9 Ir3 N2 O15 S3, monoclinic, P21/c, a = 11.8846(16), b = 12.2138(18), c = 45.809(4) Å, β = 95.960(7), V = 6613.5(14) Å, Z = 4, T = 250(2) K, μ = 6.830 mm-1, 28 772 reflections measured, 18 994 independent (R int = 0.0838), 9805 observed [I = 2σ(I)], 819 parameters, final R indices R 1 [I = 2σ(I)] = 0.0624 and wR2 (all data) = 0.1393, GOF on F 2 = 0.999, max/min residual electron density = 2.15/−2.85 e Å-3. A single crystal of the very moisture sensitive compound 3 was selected rapidly, mounted onto a glass fiber, and transferred in a cold nitrogen gas stream. Intensity data were collected with a Bruker-Nonius Kappa-CCD with graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation. Unit-cell parameters determination, data collection strategy, and integration were carried out with the Nonius EVAL-14 suite of programs (Duisenberg, A. J. M.; Kroon-Batenburg, L. M. J.; Schreurs, A. M. M. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 220). Multiscan absorption correction was applied (Blessing, R. H. Acta Crystallogr. 1995, A51, 33). The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-86 program (Sheldrick, G. M., University of Göttingen, 1986) and refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXL-97 software package (Sheldrick, G. M., University of Göttingen, Germany, 1997). Crystal data for 4. Colorless crystals, C19H22AgF3IrNO5S, fw = 733.54, triclinic P1̄, a = 8.1689(3) Å b = 11.0554(6) Å, c = 13.7066(8) Å, α = 97.128(5)°, β = 105.760(5)°, γ = 105.525(4)°, V = 1121.7 (1) Å, Z = 2, D = 2.17 g/cm3, T = 295 K, R (Rw) 0.0516 (0.0586) for 5110 observed independent reflections, GOF = 1.081. Crystal dimensions 0.18 × 0.35 × 0.39 mm; collection range θ = 1−27.50°. Absorption correction was applied using DIFABS (Walker, N.; Stuart, D. Acta Crystallogr. 1983, A39, 158). The structure was determined by direct methods and subsequent difference Fourier syntheses and refined by full matrix least-squares on F by using the programs of the PC version of CRYSTALS (Betteridge, P. W.; Carruthers, J. R.; Cooper, R. I.; Prout, K.; Watkin, D. J. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 1487). All non-hydrogen atoms excluding those of free triflate were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions, and their coordinates were refined with an overall isotropic thermal parameter.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of 3. A solution of 1b (18 mg, 0.04 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (15 mL) was added to (CuOTf)2.C6H6 (10 mg, 0.02 mmol), and the mixture was stirred for 3 h. The solvent was reduced under vacuum to give an off-gray microcrystalline solid. This solid was washed with benzene and recrystallized from CH3CN/Et2O to give golden crystals. Yield:  84%. (m = 22 mg, 0.011 mmol). IR (KBr disc):  v(CO) 1558 cm-1, 1508 cm-1, v(SO) 1261 cm-1, v(C−F) 1034 cm-1. 1H NMR (300 MHz, acetone-d 6):  δ = 1.92 (s, 15H, η5-Cp*), 2.08 (br, 3H, coordinated CH3−CN), 5.00 (s, 4H, diene) ppm. Analysis calcld for C53H60O15F9S3NCu2Ir3.C6H6; C 35.43; H 3.33; N 0.70. Found C 35.30; H 3.32; N 0.59.

Synthesis of 4. A solution of 1b (50 mg, 0.11 mmol) in CH2Cl2 was added to AgOTf (41 mg, 0.16 mmol), and the mixture was stirred for 12 h. The solvent was reduced under vacuum to give an off-gray microcrystalline solid. This solid was recrystallized from CH3CN/Et2O to give colorless crystals. Yield:  70% (m = 56.4 mg, 0.077 mmol). IR (KBr disc):  v(−C⋮N) 2260 v(CO) 1610 cm-1, 1577 cm-1, v(SO) 1278 cm-1, v(C−F) 1038 cm-1. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3CN):  δ 2.02 (s, 15H, η5-Cp*), 2.45 (s, 3H, coordinated CH3−CN), 4.77 (s, 4H, diene) ppm. Analysis calcld for C19H22O5F3SNAgIr; C 31.1; H 3.0; N 1.9. Found C 31.7; H 3.2; N 2.1.

cln_elements.content:
Discrete coinage metal complexes with d10---d10 interactions continue to generate much interest in terms of their luminescent properties. The short metal−metal contacts found in these metal complexes are believed to play a dominant role in the excited-state properties. Thus, we investigated the photophysical properties of our 1D supramolecular assemblies {[Ag3(LM)2(CH3CN)2(OTf)][LM](OTf)2} n (2a,b) because they present shorter Ag···Ag (3.37 Å) contacts compared to 4. Complexes 2a,b showed weak emissions at room temperature (298 K) in a solution of CH3CN with emission maxima at 421 nm (2a) and at 406 nm (2b). Repeating the above measurements but at 77 K glass in butyronitrile, complexes 2a and 2b exhibited a slight blue shift with emission maxima at 408 nm for 2a and 402 nm for 2b, respectively (Figure S, Supporting Information). We believe that these emissions are mainly due to a metal-perturbed intraligand emission of benzoquinone since benzoquinone also emits at similar energies, suggesting that these polymers dissociate in solution into oligomers that are in equilibrium. Attempts to measure the luminescent properties in the solid state were not successful since the complexes do not emit in the solid state, preventing a direct correlation of the emissive properties with the Ag···Ag interaction.

X-ray Structural Analysis of 3 and 4. Crystals of 3 and 4 suitable for X-ray studies were grown from CH3CN/Et2O. In all cases, X-ray data collections with Mo Kα radiation were carried out at 250 K (3) and 298 K (4) using a Enraf-Nonius diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector. Crystal data for 3. Golden crystals:  C55 H63 Cu2 F9 Ir3 N2 O15 S3, monoclinic, P21/c, a = 11.8846(16), b = 12.2138(18), c = 45.809(4) Å, β = 95.960(7), V = 6613.5(14) Å, Z = 4, T = 250(2) K, μ = 6.830 mm-1, 28 772 reflections measured, 18 994 independent (R int = 0.0838), 9805 observed [I = 2σ(I)], 819 parameters, final R indices R 1 [I = 2σ(I)] = 0.0624 and wR2 (all data) = 0.1393, GOF on F 2 = 0.999, max/min residual electron density = 2.15/−2.85 e Å-3. A single crystal of the very moisture sensitive compound 3 was selected rapidly, mounted onto a glass fiber, and transferred in a cold nitrogen gas stream. Intensity data were collected with a Bruker-Nonius Kappa-CCD with graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation. Unit-cell parameters determination, data collection strategy, and integration were carried out with the Nonius EVAL-14 suite of programs (Duisenberg, A. J. M.; Kroon-Batenburg, L. M. J.; Schreurs, A. M. M. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 220). Multiscan absorption correction was applied (Blessing, R. H. Acta Crystallogr. 1995, A51, 33). The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-86 program (Sheldrick, G. M., University of Göttingen, 1986) and refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXL-97 software package (Sheldrick, G. M., University of Göttingen, Germany, 1997). Crystal data for 4. Colorless crystals, C19H22AgF3IrNO5S, fw = 733.54, triclinic P1̄, a = 8.1689(3) Å b = 11.0554(6) Å, c = 13.7066(8) Å, α = 97.128(5)°, β = 105.760(5)°, γ = 105.525(4)°, V = 1121.7 (1) Å, Z = 2, D = 2.17 g/cm3, T = 295 K, R (Rw) 0.0516 (0.0586) for 5110 observed independent reflections, GOF = 1.081. Crystal dimensions 0.18 × 0.35 × 0.39 mm; collection range θ = 1−27.50°. Absorption correction was applied using DIFABS (Walker, N.; Stuart, D. Acta Crystallogr. 1983, A39, 158). The structure was determined by direct methods and subsequent difference Fourier syntheses and refined by full matrix least-squares on F by using the programs of the PC version of CRYSTALS (Betteridge, P. W.; Carruthers, J. R.; Cooper, R. I.; Prout, K.; Watkin, D. J. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 1487). All non-hydrogen atoms excluding those of free triflate were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions, and their coordinates were refined with an overall isotropic thermal parameter.

The short metal-metal contacts found in these metal complexes are believed to play a dominant role in the excited-state properties. Thus, we investigated the photophysical properties of our 1D supramolecular assemblies {[Ag3(LM)2(CH3CN)2(OTf)][LM](OTf)2} n  (2a,b) because they present shorter Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag (3.37 Å) contacts compared to 4. Complexes 2a,b showed weak emissions at room temperature (298 K) in a solution of CH3CN with emission maxima at 421 nm (2a) and at 406 nm (2b). Repeating the above measurements but at 77 K glass in butyronitrile, complexes 2a and 2b exhibited a slight blue shift with emission maxima at 408 nm for 2a and 402 nm for 2b, respectively (Figure S, Supporting Information). We believe that these emissions are mainly due to a metal-perturbed intraligand emission of benzoquinone since benzoquinone also emits at similar energies, suggesting that these polymers dissociate in solution into oligomers that are in equilibrium. Attempts to measure the luminescent properties in the solid state were not successful since the complexes do not emit in the solid state, preventing a direct correlation of the emissive properties with the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction. 

 X-ray Structural Analysis of 3 and 4. Crystals of 3 and 4 suitable for X-ray studies were grown from CH3CN/Et2O. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXS-86 program (Sheldrick, G. M., University of Göttingen, 1986) and refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXL-97 software package (Sheldrick, G. M., University of Göttingen, Germany, 1997). Crystal data for 4. Colorless crystals, C19H22AgF3IrNO5S, fw = 733.54, triclinic P1̄, a = 8.1689(3) Å b = 11.0554(6) Å, c = 13.7066(8) Å, α = 97.128(5)°, β = 105.760(5)°, γ = 105.525(4)°, V = 1121.7 (1) Å, Z = 2, D = 2.17 g/cm3, T = 295 K, R (Rw) 0.0516 (0.0586) for 5110 observed independent reflections, GOF = 1.081. The structure was determined by direct methods and subsequent difference Fourier syntheses and refined by full matrix least-squares on F by using the programs of the PC version of CRYSTALS (Betteridge, P. W.; Carruthers, J. R.; Cooper, R. I.; Prout, K.; Watkin, D. J. J. Appl. Crystallogr. 2003, 36, 1487). All non-hydrogen atoms excluding those of free triflate were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions, and their coordinates were refined with an overall isotropic thermal parameter.

metadata.title:
Self-Assembly of One- and Two-Dimensional Coordination Polymers
with Quinonoid Backbones Featuring Coinage Metals as Nodes
